('1998050', 'American shoppers see price savings in many goods as result of protracted financial crisis in Asia; prices have dropped as much as 20 percent from year ago in some categories; domestic purchase deflator--which tracks prices paid by consumers for goods sold in United States, both imported and American-made--fell one-tenth of percent for first time since 1959; biggest bargains are at lower-priced or midpriced stores, which tend to buy more products from Asia; collapse of currencies throughout much of Asia means dollar buys much more in countries producing everything from mascara wands to Barbie dolls; desperate manufacturers in Asia are cutting prices to unload goods that otherwise would go unsold; graph (M)')('1998050', "Justice Dept receives letter from 26 computer industry executives saying that any delay in introduction of Microsoft's Windows 98 will harm computer industry, particularly two million programmers who write software for Windows-based computers, and equal number who work in computer services industry; executives claim that quantifying these costs is nearly impossible; companies including giants like General Electric and Viacom only hint at their obligations in their filings and annual reports, leaving people who invest in their stocks, live near their properties and work in their factories in the dark about when they plan to make amends, and how much they expect to spend; only 37 percent of 1,359 official Superfund sites have been cleaned up in 18 years since passage of sweeping bill; American companies will have to spend billions of dollars in coming years to finish job of decontaminating most polluted Superfund sites; familiar stainless steel curbside cookeries are small and lack basic kitchen equipment, yet 40 percent of vendors handle foods that can be hazardous; many handle tubs of raw meat and poultry, which can carry disease-causing bacteria, and food is often left unchilled and unheated--ideal for growth of E. coli, salmonella and other germs; some vendors wash hands so seldom that they use their sinks for storage space; tests arranged by New York Times showed significant undercooking in 39 of 51 cases, meaning that bacteria would not be eliminated; even though New York has more food carts than anywhere else in America, many of its regulations are far more lax than in other big cities that strictly limit what vendors can sell; inspections of city's 4,100 licensed pushcarts are spotty; scientists at National Cancer Institute, in provocative report, say that they have found that a genetic mutation that protects against AIDS virus, by preventing virus from entering microphages, emerged in Europe around time of Black Death; they find that this AIDS resistance is astonishingly common in people whose ancestors lived in areas of Europe that were ravaged by Black Death, also known as bubonic plague; map of Europe show prevalence of gene mutation that provides protection against virus that causes AIDS; Einstein added the cosmological constant to his theory of general relativity in 1917; its role was to provide a repulsive force in order to keep universe from theoretically collapsing under its own weight; Einstein abandoned cosmological constant when universe turned out to be expanding, but in succeeding years, cosmological constant has stubbornly refused to die; this year, cosmological constant has been propelled back into the news as an explanation for widely reported discovery, based on observations of distant exploding stars, that some kind of 'funny energy' is apparently accelerating expansion of universe; photo; putative planet, scorching hot and larger than Jupiter, is in constellation Taurus about 450 light-years from Earth; discovery team at news conference at NASA shows image of two stars circling each other, with third, much smaller, object visible but dimmer; existence of extra-solar planets has until now been inferred mainly from gravitational wobbling induced in their parent stars, but never seen directly; team leader Dr Susan Tereby, founder of Extrasolar Research Corp, says planet TMR-1C has apparently been expelled from its binary-star system and is hurtling outward at about 12 miles per second; says very young, very large planet apparently was created at about same time as two sunlike stars it orbited, but orbit was unstable, and it ws expelled from system by gravitational 'slingshot'; planet seems destined to be rogue, forever drifting outward; Tereby photo; other astronomers comment (M)")('1998052', 'Article discusses plans by NBC and Turner Sports to form new professional football league discussed; various reactions to announcement noted (M)')('1998052', 'Mississippi authorities arrest three aging Klansmen and revive charges against them in 1966 murder of Vernon F Dahmer Sr, civil rights leader; Housing Assistance Council, Washington-based consulting group that studies rural housing, says about 800,000 of current workers lack adequate shelter; in recent years, agricultural work force has changed in ways that make it harder for Government to improve workers' living conditions, whether by providing housing itself or pressuring growers to improve housing they provide; most important is that migrant work force, once composed mainly of US citizens, is largely made up of immigrants from Mexico and Central America, 40 percent of them in US illegally; over past decade, Federal and state governments, working with growers, have built tens of thousands of housing units for migrants;
